questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of lightening of his skin on both hands, under his eyes, and on his neck for the past 2 years. During this period the lesions slowly grew in size. There is no itchiness or pain. He regularly visits his family in India. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows irregular, sharply demarcated, depigmented skin patches on the dorsum of both hands, in the periocular region, and on the neck. Sensation of the skin is intact. The lesions fluoresce blue-white under Wood lamp. Dermoscopy shows perilesional hyperpigmentation and telangiectasia. Which of the following findings is most likely to be associated with this patient's condition?

choices.text: Hyphae and yeast cells on KOH scraping
Elevated anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody levels in serum
Acid-fast bacilli DNA on PCR of tissue
Poorly developed retinal pigment epithelium on eye examination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

KOH scrapings showing both hyphae and yeast cells arranged in a spaghetti-and-meatballs appearance is characteristic of pityriasis versicolor (PV), a fungal infection that can manifest with scaly hypopigmented macules and patches on the upper trunk in adolescents and young adults. It has a higher incidence in tropical climates and should be considered in this patient with regular travel to India. However, other common findings include hyperpigmented and erythematous macules and patches. Wood lamp examination of PV lesions shows yellow-green fluorescent areas, unlike the blue-white areas of vitiligo. Moreover, perilesional hyperpigmentation and telangiectasia would not be expected.
Image Description:

Back of a patient

Multiple round, well-demarcated, confluent, depigmented macules are visible.

This finding indicates pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia species.

B) CORRECT:

Elevated anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody levels are a typical finding in autoimmune thyroid disorders (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis), which are the most common autoimmune conditions associated with vitiligo. Roughly 20% of patients with vitiligo have a comorbid autoimmune disease. Less commonly associated conditions include type 1 diabetes, alopecia areata, inflammatory bowel disease, and psoriasis. Given the strong association with autoimmune thyroid disorders, it is reasonable to evaluate all patients with confirmed vitiligo for thyroid function with TSH and antithyroglobulin antibodies.
Image Description:

Localization: dorsal and palmar side of both hands and fingers

Lesion: multiple, partially confluent, irregularly shaped, well demarcated, depigmented macules

C) INCORRECT:

PCR testing of a skin biopsy that is positive for Mycobacterium leprae, an acid-fast bacilli, is diagnostic for leprosy, which should be considered in this patient with regular travel to a leprosy-endemic country (e.g., India). Tuberculoid leprosy also causes hypopigmented macules. However, additional clinical findings include plaques and papules, hair loss, hypoesthesia of depigmented skin lesions, and nerve palsies.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent hypopigmented patches with erythematous borders are visible on the patient's back.

D) INCORRECT:

Poorly developed retinal pigment epithelium is found in patients with oculocutaneous albinism, a form of albinism that causes widespread hypopigmentation or depigmentation of the hair, skin, and eyes. Patients with albinism have a congenital defect in melanin synthesis. However, this patient has acquired depigmentation starting at 21 years of age, and most of his skin (including hair) has normal pigmentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal angiomyolipomas commonly develop in patients with tuberous sclerosis (TS), which typically manifests with hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf spots) that also appear as blue-white fluorescent areas under Wood lamp examination. However, TS manifests in childhood and also leads to intellectual disability, seizures, and angiofibromas on the face.
questions.hint: Sharply demarcated, depigmented patches on otherwise normal skin in conjunction with perilesional hyperpigmentation, telangiectasia, and a blue-white fluorescence on Wood lamp examination are consistent with vitiligo.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of multiple patches on his trunk and thighs that are lighter than the rest of his skin. He has similar depigmented lesions on his hands and feet and around the mouth. The patches have gradually increased in size and are not associated with itchiness, redness, numbness, or pain. His family emigrated from Indonesia 8 years ago. An image of the skin lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous mosaicism is seen in nevus depigmentosus, which would typically manifest by early childhood as a solitary, nonprogressive, hypopigmented macule with serrated borders. This patient has multiple, progressively enlarging, ivory-white/depigmented lesions with nonserrated borders, which first appeared in adolescence.

B) INCORRECT:

Malassezia globosa infection causes tinea versicolor, which can manifest with well-defined hypopigmented macules on the chest and abdomen. However, the lesions are smaller (measuring a few millimeters), have a fine, powdery scale, and are usually only mildly hypomelanotic (unlike the depigmented ivory-white lesions in this patient).

Tinea versicolor lesions can coalesce to form large lesions. In such a scenario, however, the larger lesion would have irregular borders and would be surrounded by multiple, smaller satellite lesions.
Image Description:

Back of a patient

Multiple round, well-demarcated, confluent, depigmented macules are visible.

This finding indicates pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia species.

C) INCORRECT:

Tyrosinase deficiency is the most common cause of oculocutaneous albinism, which would result in depigmentation. However, depigmentation would have been present since birth and would affect the entire skin, unlike the patchy involvement of skin in this patient. In addition, patients usually have a history of visual impairment, as well as depigmented hair and light blue, translucent irises.

D) CORRECT:

Vitiligo is a common skin condition that is thought to be caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. The areas of depigmentation commonly involve the face (e.g., perioral and periocular regions), neck, scalp, acral surfaces (e.g., hands), extensor surfaces, or genitalia. Vitiligo is generally a clinical diagnosis. It may be a sign of an autoimmune disorder (e.g., autoimmune thyroiditis, type 1 diabetes mellitus, pernicious anemia), and patients with vitiligo should be tested for thyroid dysfunction and markers of autoimmune disease (e.g., ANA).

Patients with limited disease can be treated with topical steroids or topical application of calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus, pimecrolimus). Those with extensive or refractory disease can be treated with phototherapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Overactivation of the mTOR signaling pathway is seen in tuberous sclerosis (TS) because the proteins tuberin and hamartin, which inhibit the mTOR pathway, are nonfunctional. TS can cause multiple, oval/polygonal, hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf macules) on the trunk. However, these macules would have already appeared during infancy or early childhood, and other features such as Shagreen patches, angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum), developmental delay, a history of seizures, and/or intellectual disability would be present by the time the patient reached adolescence.

F) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, which can manifest with hypopigmented macules. Also, a history of migration from Indonesia is a risk factor for leprosy. However, the skin lesions would be insensate, and other features such as nerve thickening would be present.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent hypopigmented patches with erythematous borders are visible on the patient's back.

G) INCORRECT:

Hyalinization of the dermis can be seen in patients with lichen sclerosus (LS), which can manifest with well-defined, ivory-white lesions. However, LS causes itchy papules or plaques with wrinkling of the epidermis (unlike the nonpruritic macules with normal skin texture in this patient), typically occurs in females, and more commonly affects the genital region.
Image Description:

Upper back of a female patient

Multiple white plaques with a dry, wrinkled appearance are visible.

These findings are suggestive of extragenital lichen sclerosus. However, the diagnosis requires histological confirmation.
questions.hint: Sharply demarcated, depigmented skin macules on otherwise normal skin in an asymptomatic patient suggest vitiligo.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of multiple patches on her face, hands, abdomen, and feet that are lighter than the rest of her skin. The patches began to appear 3 years ago and have been gradually increasing in size since. There is no associated itchiness, redness, numbness, or pain. She emigrated from India 2 years ago. An image of the lesions on her face is shown. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A complete absence of tyrosinase activity results in oculocutaneous albinism, which results in the congenital absence of pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes rather than the relatively recent onset of patchy depigmentation only. However, depigmentation would have been present since birth and would affect the entire skin, not just patches, as seen here. In addition, the patient would have a history of visual impairment as well as depigmented hair and light blue, translucent irises.
Image Description:

Four Chinese children with oculocutaneous albinism (OCA).

In individuals with OCA, reduction or complete absence of melanin pigment results in abnormal eye development as well as light-colored hair, skin, and eyes. However, the severity of visual impairment and the degree of hypopigmentation (as seen here in the variations of hair and iris color) may vary.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory skin lesions (e.g., eczema, herpes zoster) can cause hypopigmentation after the inflammation resolves. However, this patient does not have a history of any inflammatory skin disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, which can present with hypopigmented macules. Furthermore, a history of migration from India is a risk factor for leprosy. However, the skin lesions would be insensate, and other features such as nerve thickening would be present.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent hypopigmented patches with erythematous borders are visible on the patient's back.

D) INCORRECT:

Malassezia globosa infection causes tinea versicolor, which can manifest with well-defined hypopigmented macules on the chest and abdomen. Tinea versicolor lesions may grow together to form large lesions with irregular borders with multiple smaller satellite lesions, similar to the skin findings in this patient. However, the lesions are small (measuring only a few millimeters), have a fine, powdery scale, and are usually only mildly hypomelanotic, unlike the depigmented ivory-white lesions in this patient.

Tinea versicolor lesions may coalesce to form large lesions. In such a scenario, however, the larger lesion would have irregular borders and would be surrounded by multiple, smaller satellite lesions.
Image Description:

Pea-sized, partly confluent, macular lesions with complete depigmentation can be seen on the upper back of this patient following UV-light exposure.

Irregular borders and satellite lesions are suggestive of pityriasis versicolor alba, caused by Malassezia globosa infection.

E) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the TSC2 gene and a subsequent defect in the tuberin protein are seen in tuberous sclerosis, a condition that may cause multiple, oval/polygonal, hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf macules) on the trunk. However, these macules would have already appeared during infancy or early childhood, and other features such as Shagreen patches, angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum), developmental delay, a history of seizures, and/or intellectual disability would be present by the time the patient reached adolescence.

F) CORRECT:

Vitiligo is a common skin condition that is thought to be caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. The areas of depigmentation commonly involve the face (e.g., perioral and periocular regions), neck, scalp, acral surfaces (e.g., hands), extensor surfaces, and genitalia. Vitiligo is generally a clinical diagnosis. It may be a sign of an autoimmune disorder (e.g., autoimmune thyroiditis, type 1 diabetes mellitus, pernicious anemia), and patients with vitiligo should be tested for thyroid dysfunction and markers of autoimmune disease (e.g., ANA).
questions.hint: The presence of sharply demarcated, depigmented skin macules on otherwise normal skin in a patient with no further symptoms is highly suggestive of vitiligo.

questions.text:
A 11-year-old boy presents with diffuse areas of skin lightening. Months ago, he developed a patch of skin discoloration on his lower arm and hand; it was treated with topical clotrimazole. After a period of prolonged sun exposure, the patchiness seemed to intensify and spread. Despite the boys limited sun exposure during the past few months, the skin changes have persisted. There have been no recent changes in his skincare products or laundry detergents.
Physical examination reveals generalized, patchy depigmentation without surface scale. The depigmentation is most prominent on the bilateral extensor surfaces of his extremities but is also distributed over his torso and back (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vitiligo is the most common depigmentation disorder, with a prevalence of 0.5% to 2.0% worldwide. It results from autoimmune destruction of epidermal melanocytes and can be associated with other autoimmune conditions, most commonly of the thyroid.

There are two main varieties of vitiligo: nonsegmental (or generalized) and segmental, with the latter characterized by a regional distribution, often along the lines of Blaschko. Nonsegmental vitiligo represents 85% to 90% of all cases, but in children, segmental vitiligo is more common, representing up to 30% of cases. The present case is an example of generalized vitiligo.

The depigmentation in vitiligo becomes more obvious after sun exposure or sun tanning, particularly in white or light-skinned patients, because of increased discrepancies in skin pigmentation between affected areas (which remain white) and unaffected areas (which are able to tan). This also occurs with hypopigmentation in tinea versicolor and pityriasis alba, but these conditions are scaly whereas vitiligo is not.

Key learning point: Progressive, generalized depigmentation that is present on the extremities, back, and torso and that appears more prominent after sun exposure is most likely vitiligo.

B) INCORRECT:

Piebaldism is an autosomal dominant condition that manifests at birth with depigmented patches that are interspersed with normally pigmented skin. It is associated with a white forelock.

C) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis alba (scaly white skin) is a mild form of eczema that commonly involves the face and upper extremities. The lesions are round or irregular plaques and are subtly scaly. They are red, pink, or skin colored and are often hypopigmented (not depigmented) because of decreased pigment transfer from melanocytes to skin cells secondary to mild underlying inflammation. The skin hypopigmentation gradually improves over time.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypomelanosis of Ito is a less common disorder that is characterized by sporadic, patterned regions of skin hypopigmentation that follow the lines of Blaschko. It manifests at birth or in the first months to years of life and may be associated with neurologic, skeletal, and ophthalmologic anomalies.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea versicolor, most commonly found in adolescents and young adults, is a fungal disorder of the skin caused by the skin flora Malassezia furfur. The dyspigmentation in tinea versicolor is hypopigmentation rather than depigmentation and is often also accompanied by hyperpigmentation (thus, versicolor). Tinea versicolor is usually isolated to the oily, lipid-rich or sebaceous areas of the body, including the chest, back, and proximal extremities, and is marked by subtle overlying scale, whereas vitiligo has no scale at any point in its course. A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is diagnostic, revealing fungal hyphae and spores.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with diffuse areas of skin lightening. Months ago, he developed a patch of skin discoloration on his lower arm and hand. After a period of prolonged sun exposure, the patchiness seemed to intensify. Despite the boys limited sun exposure during the past few months, the skin changes have persisted. Physical examination reveals generalized, patchy depigmentation without surface scale. The depigmentation is most prominent on the bilateral extensor surfaces of his extremities but is also distributed over his torso and back. A photograph of the skin findings is shown. What of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vitiligo is the most common depigmentation disorder, with a prevalence of 0.5% to 2.0% worldwide.

There are two main varieties of vitiligo: nonsegmental (or generalized) and segmental, with the latter characterized by a regional distribution, often along the lines of Blaschko. Nonsegmental vitiligo represents 85% to 90% of all cases, but in children, segmental vitiligo is more common, representing up to 30% of cases. The present case is an example of generalized vitiligo.

Pityriasis alba (scaly white skin) is a mild form of eczema that commonly involves the face and upper extremities. The lesions are round or irregular plaques and are subtly scaly. They are red, pink, or skin colored and are often hypopigmented (not depigmented) because of decreased pigment transfer from melanocytes to skin cells secondary to mild underlying inflammation. The skin hypopigmentation gradually improves over time.

Hypomelanosis of Ito is a less common disorder that is characterized by sporadic, patterned regions of skin hypopigmentation that follow the lines of Blaschko. It manifests at birth or in the first months to years of life and may be associated with neurologic, skeletal, and ophthalmologic anomalies.

Tinea versicolor, most commonly found in adolescents and young adults, is a fungal disorder of the skin caused by the skin flora Malassezia furfur. The dyspigmentation in tinea versicolor is hypopigmentation rather than depigmentation and is often also accompanied by hyperpigmentation (thus, versicolor). Tinea versicolor is usually isolated to the oily, lipid-rich or sebaceous areas of the body, including the chest, back, and proximal extremities, and is marked by subtle overlying scale, whereas vitiligo has no scale at any point in its course. A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is diagnostic, revealing fungal hyphae and spores.
questions.hint: This patient's condition results from autoimmune destruction of epidermal melanocytes and can be associated with other autoimmune conditions, most commonly of the thyroid.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with several sharply demarcated areas of lighter-colored skin on her hands and forearms that have expanded slowly over the past six months. She has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. Physical examination shows multiple oval patches of complete pigment loss, each measuring 12 cm, without surrounding erythema. There is no itching or scaling.
Which mechanism best explains this patients skin findings?

choices.text: Defective embryologic migration of neural crest cells
Fungal colonization within the stratum corneum
Genetic deficiency of tyrosinase enzyme activity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective embryologic migration of neural crest cells results in congenital pigmentary disorders like piebaldism, evident at birth with stable depigmented areas. This patient's gradually expanding depigmented patches and association with autoimmune hypothyroidism indicate an acquired, not congenital, process.

B) INCORRECT:

Fungal colonization, as seen in pityriasis versicolor, causes mild hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation with fine scaling, typically on the trunk. This patient's sharply demarcated, depigmented patches on the hands and forearms, without scaling or erythema, are inconsistent with a superficial fungal infection.

C) CORRECT:

Vitiligo manifests with sharply demarcated depigmented patches due to autoimmune destruction of melanocytes, the cells responsible for melanin production. Autoreactive T cells target melanocyte-specific antigens, leading to their destruction. The condition often coexists with other autoimmune diseases, such as hypothyroidism, due to shared genetic and inflammatory pathways. The absence of melanocytes results in complete pigment loss, as seen in this patient.

Key learning point: Vitiligo is caused by an autoimmune attack against melanocytes, leading to depigmented patches on the skin.

D) INCORRECT:

A genetic deficiency of tyrosinase enzyme activity causes oculocutaneous albinism, characterized by diffuse pigmentation abnormalities from birth. This patient's localized, gradually developing depigmented patches and autoimmune thyroid disease suggest an acquired process, not a congenital enzyme deficiency.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to your clinic with a 2-year history of multiple patches on his trunk and thighs that are lighter than the rest of his skin. He also has similar depigmented lesions on his hands, feet, and around his mouth. The patches have gradually increased in size and are not associated with itchiness, redness, numbness, or pain. His family emigrated from Indonesia 8 years ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are normal. An image of the skin lesions is provided. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malassezia globosa infection causes tinea versicolor, which can manifest with well-defined hypopigmented macules on the chest and abdomen. However, the lesions are smaller (measuring a few millimeters), have a fine, powdery scale, and are usually only mildly hypomelanotic (unlike the depigmented ivory-white lesions in this patient).

Tinea versicolor lesions can coalesce to form large lesions. In such a scenario, however, the larger lesion would have irregular borders and would be surrounded by multiple, smaller satellite lesions.

B) CORRECT:

Vitiligo is a common skin condition that is thought to be caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. The areas of depigmentation commonly involve the face (e.g., perioral and periocular regions), neck, scalp, acral surfaces (e.g., hands), extensor surfaces, or genitalia. Vitiligo is generally a clinical diagnosis. It may be a sign of an autoimmune disorder (e.g., autoimmune thyroiditis, type 1 diabetes mellitus, pernicious anemia), and patients with vitiligo should be tested for thyroid dysfunction and markers of autoimmune disease (e.g., ANA).

Patients with limited disease can be treated with topical steroids or topical application of calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus, pimecrolimus). Those with extensive or refractory disease can be treated with phototherapy.

Key learning point: Vitiligo is caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes, leading to well-demarcated depigmented patches on the skin.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, which can manifest with hypopigmented macules. Also, a history of migration from Indonesia is a risk factor for leprosy. However, the skin lesions would be insensate, and other features such as nerve thickening would be present.

D) INCORRECT:

Tyrosinase deficiency is the most common cause of oculocutaneous albinism, which would result in depigmentation. However, depigmentation would have been present since birth and would affect the entire skin, unlike the patchy involvement of skin in this patient. In addition, patients usually have a history of visual impairment, as well as depigmented hair and light blue, translucent irises.

E) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous mosaicism is seen in nevus depigmentosus, which would typically manifest by early childhood as a solitary, nonprogressive, hypopigmented macule with serrated borders. This patient has multiple, progressively enlarging, ivory-white/depigmented lesions with nonserrated borders, which first appeared in adolescence.
questions.hint: Sharply demarcated, depigmented skin macules on otherwise normal skin in an asymptomatic patient suggest vitiligo.

questions.text: You are seeing a 10-year-old boy who presents with diffuse areas of skin lightening. Several months ago, he developed a patch of skin discoloration on his lower arm and hand. The patchiness became more noticeable after prolonged sun exposure. Although he has had limited sun exposure in recent months, the skin changes have persisted. On examination, there is generalized, patchy depigmentation without surface scale. The depigmentation is most prominent on the bilateral extensor surfaces of his extremities, but also involves his torso and back. A photograph of the skin findings is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypomelanosis of Ito is a less common disorder that is characterized by sporadic, patterned regions of skin hypopigmentation that follow the lines of Blaschko. It manifests at birth or in the first months to years of life and may be associated with neurologic, skeletal, and ophthalmologic anomalies.

B) INCORRECT:

Piebaldism is an autosomal dominant condition that manifests at birth with depigmented patches that are interspersed with normally pigmented skin. It is associated with a white forelock.

C) CORRECT:

Vitiligo is the most common depigmentation disorder, with a prevalence of 0.5% to 2.0% worldwide.

There are two main varieties of vitiligo: nonsegmental (or generalized) and segmental, with the latter characterized by a regional distribution, often along the lines of Blaschko. Nonsegmental vitiligo represents 85% to 90% of all cases, but in children, segmental vitiligo is more common, representing up to 30% of cases. The present case is an example of generalized vitiligo.

The depigmentation in vitiligo becomes more obvious after sun exposure or sun tanning, particularly in white or light-skinned patients, because of increased discrepancies in skin pigmentation between affected areas (which remain white) and unaffected areas (which are able to tan). This also occurs with hypopigmentation in tinea versicolor and pityriasis alba, but these conditions are scaly whereas vitiligo is not.

Key learning point: Progressive, generalized depigmentation that is present on the extremities, back, and torso and that appears more prominent after sun exposure is most likely vitiligo.

D) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis alba (scaly white skin) is a mild form of eczema that commonly involves the face and upper extremities. The lesions are round or irregular plaques and are subtly scaly. They are red, pink, or skin colored and are often hypopigmented (not depigmented) because of decreased pigment transfer from melanocytes to skin cells secondary to mild underlying inflammation. The skin hypopigmentation gradually improves over time.

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea versicolor, most commonly found in adolescents and young adults, is a fungal disorder of the skin caused by the skin flora Malassezia furfur. The dyspigmentation in tinea versicolor is hypopigmentation rather than depigmentation and is often also accompanied by hyperpigmentation (thus, versicolor). Tinea versicolor is usually isolated to the oily, lipid-rich or sebaceous areas of the body, including the chest, back, and proximal extremities, and is marked by subtle overlying scale, whereas vitiligo has no scale at any point in its course. A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is diagnostic, revealing fungal hyphae and spores.
questions.hint: This patient's condition results from autoimmune destruction of epidermal melanocytes and can be associated with other autoimmune conditions, most commonly of the thyroid.
